div.p: 1. V:30. Tuesday

Begun the version of the 35th. Psalm— Miss Roberdeau made for me a copy of my Stanzas upon the Valley at the foot of Penn’s Hill— I wrote a Letter to Miss E Susan Quincy enclosing them for an Inscription to the drawing which she made some years since of the house in which I was born and of which I have requested from her a copy. Mr Gallatin and Dr Wainwright called on me at ten to accompany me to the Meeting of the Literary Convention, to which I had received a printed circular invitation.— They asked me if I should be willing to preside at the Meeting.— I told them I had understood that Mr Gallatin had presided at the last year’s Meeting— He was certainly much more competent to the same service now than me, who had not been informed even of the objects of the Meeting. They said Mr Gallatin had not presided last year; but a Mr. Bates the President of Middlebury College, and that as the Meeting was attended by a considerable number of Gentlemen from other States who came by invitation, it was thought particularly desirable that the President should not be a resident of New-York. I said, in
that case my services should be at the disposal of the Meeting. I accompanied them immediately. The Convention was held at the Assistant Alderman’s room in the City Hall— I was elected President of the Convention by nomination— Albert Gallatin and Edward P. Livingston, the Lieutt. Governor of the State were chosen Vice-Presidents—John Delafield, andSecretaries. For the proceedings of this Convention I must refer myself to the Newspapers, and to the pamphlet in which they are to be published. I found myself in a situation totally new and unexpected. Called to preside over a Meeting of Literary men, held in public, to discuss subjects of literature and Science, but of what specific character I had received no previous intimation— Of my unfitness for this station I had the most profound conviction—the meeting being not only public, but with Stenographers attending to report the proceedings in several of the daily papers; besides Mr Stansberry employed to report for the Convention itself— I had come without the most distant idea of presiding, and intending rather to listen than to take an active part in the proceedings myself— What could I do but implore a blessing from him who directs the steps of the man that walketh?— What can I do but abide in humble submission by his will? The Meeting was opened by prayer— A Letter was read from Professor Pesaro, and several Letters of excuse and apology— After some initiatory proceedings the meeting was adjourned till ten to-morrow Morning— Returning to my lodgings I received several visitors and numerous Cards— Mrs Adams with the portion of our family now journeying with us had left the City at Noon; proceeding to Philadelphia— Among my visitors was Mr Ratcliff, heretofore Consul of the United States at Lima in Peru—appointed by me— He has a plan for making a Railway across the Isthmus of Panama, concerning which he left a Memoir with me; for which he is to call again before the end of the week and resume a conversation with me— I dined with the Ex-Chancellor Kent. His relatives Philip and John Hone, were there, and two or three other Gentlemen— Mrs Kent the only Lady.— In the Evening I called to see in his chamber Mr Oliver Wolcott, who is lodging at this house— Had an hour’s conversation with him, and found him declining in the vale of years— W. L. Stone, the Editor of the Commercial Advertiser called, and spoke of his intention to address to me a series of Letters upon the subject of Masonry and Anti-Masonry— He said there was great misrepresentation upon the subject derogatory to the Memory of De Witt Clinton, which it would be in his power to rectify— He is to see me again.— I spent the remainder of the Evening and supped with Mr Sampson, the Irish refugee, who was some years an inhabitant of Georgetown, near Washington— Met there Matthew Carey, Dr M’Neven and several other learned Gentlemen it was near Midnight when I returned to my lodgings.
2. VI. Wednesday.

Attended the Literary Convention Morning and afternoon— A paper was read by Mr Lleras of the Republic of Columbia, upon the subject of the State of Education in South-America generally, and in that Republic especially— A Committee was appointed to report a plan, for a National Literary and Scientific Institution— A Resolution that it is expedient to establish such an institution had been adopted by the last year’s Convention.— I was now placed upon this Committee— After the adjournment of the morning the Committee met at the house of the Revd. Dr James M. Matthews, and discussed the plan— Questions were started, what should be the title of the Society—Academy—Association Society—Institute—Institution; not very momentous which— Whether the numbers should be limited— How divided into Classes whether of domestic and foreign members—of Resident and honorary? and under what divisions of the Sciences— The practice of the French Institute was referred to— Dr Matthews
undertook to draw up the report— I dined in the Apartment of George Sullivan, with him and his family— There was also a young Lawyer named Warner engaged with Sullivan in a cause now upon trial before the Chancellor of the State Walworth in which individuals are claimants against the Trinity Church of this City.— A cause involving as Mr Sullivan says rights of property to the amount of two or three Millions of dollars.— The Convention met at 5 in the afternoon, and the plan for a National Literary and Scientific Society was reported. There was some discussion upon the title to be adopted, but that point was soon postponed for further consideration, and the main debate, a warm one was upon the question whether should be of a limited number. It was half past eight when the Convention adjourned— I had yesterday received invitations to visit the Libraries of the Mercantile and of the Mechanic Associations. A Mr William Wood had called upon me with a Letter from R. B. Brown President of the Mercantile Library and I had agreed to go whenever I should have the time and this day I received a similar invitation to visit the Apprentices Library from John Stephens junr. President of that Society— A second invitation this day from Mr Brown included the members of the Convention, and I read it to them. The Presidents and a Committee from Both the Societies, attended the afternoon Meeting of the Convention, and immediately after the adjournment I accompanied the Committee’s and visited both the Libraries and reading room. As also the Lecture room of the American Lyceum— These are excellent Institutions. the Mercantile Library is for the benefit of the Merchants Clerks, and that of the Apprentices for the youth of the Mechanic Professions— At both I saw numbers of young men assiduously reading and both the Catalogues of the books, and several other pamphlets relating to both Institutions were given me— Also the pamphlet containing the proceedings of a Convention in May last, to form an American Lyceum— There was a Type-foundery which I was also to have seen but the adjournment of the Convention was too late, and it was shut up— After I returned to my lodgings Mr Sullivan came and sat with me an hour in Conversation.
3. V:30. Thursday.

I called this morning early upon my old friend Joseph Pitcairn who had visited me, and sent me an invitation to dine with him on Saturday.— I told him it was my intention to leave the City Saturday Morning; but that if I should not I would accept his invitation— I likewise called on Mrs Cushing at her relation’s 21. Beekman Street and made a small payment to her as had been requested by my Son John— A ten O’Clock I attended the Meeting of the Literary Convention and took the Chair.— The Plan for a National Literary and Scientific Society was fully debated, and there was so much diversity and divergence of views upon exceedingly unessential and even minute that they were on the point of taking a question to postpone the further consideration of the subject until the annual Convention of the next year; when I took the Liberty of addressing to the Meeting some remarks— I observed that at the last Annual Meeting of the Convention, a Committee had been appointed
to examine and report upon the expediency of establishing such a Society— That Committee had reported a Resolution to that effect which was adopted by the Convention. They had therefore resolved that such a Society should be instituted. The present Convention concurring in that opinion had appointed a Committee to form a plan, which was now before the Convention for consideration— The public would certainly expect that this Convention should do something more— There were debates and diversity of opinions upon points which I thought could easily be conciliated. The organization of such a Society would after all be a very simple thing— I presumed a Constitution for it could be drawn up by a Committee in 24 hours; but if after having been postponed from the last year to this, it should again be postponed from this year to the next, I saw no other prospect than that it would be postponed indefinitely— If such an institution should be established here, its principal utility must be effected by the Resident Members— It might derive and confer benefit by assembling at an annual meeting a few of its members from other parts of the Union— The fault of most of the Institutions of this kind in the United States was that they were little better than dead bodies— It was hardly worthwhile to create another of them, but much of the same character would it be to resolve every year that such a Society should be instituted and then have it undone, to be debated again the next year, when other men would be here, to whom the subject will be new, as it was now to me, and who would have to go over again the ground that we have explored. There was immediately proposed the appointment of a Committee to draw up and report a Constitution for the Society— Lieutenant Park as a delegate from West-Point read a paper proposing a National Institute of a very extensive character to be identified with this Mr. Ogilby a young School-master of the City read a long paper upon a plan of instruction upon new principles as exemplified in a School of a Mr. Jacotot in Belgium— It was referred to a Committee— I dined at Dr Wainwright’s and met there Mr Peter A. Jay, David B. Ogden, Mr Hone, and several other Gentlemen— After dinner at 6. I returned to the Convention, which had been already an hour in Session— Mr Woodbridge was reading a Report upon the expediency of introducing the Bible as a Classic to be studied in Schools and Colleges. After the Convention adjourned, the Committee to draw up a Constitution met and agreed upon the substance of the Articles—Members not to exceed two hundred—Resident and foreign Members—4. Classes 1. Mathematical and Physical Science 2 Moral and Intellectual Science 3. Literature 4. Fine Arts—An electing Committee of 15 to constitute the Society—Application to be made to the Legislature of New-York for an Act of Incorporation.— President Fiske to draw up the Constitution including these heads— I spent part of the late Evening with Sullivan, and the rest in my chamber with Joseph Blunt.
4. VI.30. Friday.

I received this morning a Letter from my wife, written at Philadelphia, Wednesday Evening— She intended to proceed the next Morning for Washington— To have her Carriage and horses there, and to return and meet me there in a week— On this I concluded to remain here till Monday Morning, as the Convention will sit here till to morrow noon.— Mr Ratcliff came again this morning, and I returned his Manuscript Memoir which I had read— He descanted largely upon the practicability and expediency of a Railway across the Isthmus of Panama— And said it would no where have to encounter
an elevation of more than 300 feet— The principal obstacle to the undertaking is the unsettled political condition of that Country— Mr. Henry Channing also called upon me and said he had supposed Mr De Wint was in the City.— He said he had just paid a visit to Mr Wolcott, but found him much changed and as he thought decayed in mind— Attended the Literary Convention— The Constitution of the National Literary and Scientific Society was reported, debated and adopted— The 9th. and last Article of it was thus— To originate the Society there shall be a Committee of fifteen, to be appointed by this Convention, who, or a majority of whom shall have power to elect eighty-five others, and these with the Committee or so many of them as may assemble at the call of the Committee shall constitute the first meeting of the Society— This was adopted, and the names of the appointing Committee of fifteen were proposed and voted in a Mass— They were J. Q. Adams, President Fisk, Professor Vethake, Revd. Dr. Thomas M’Auley, Professor Alexander, Mr Henry E Dwight, Professor Joslin, Hon. Edward P. Livingston, Chancellor Walworth, Revd Dr. Wainwright, Hon. Albert Gallatin, Revd. Dr Matthews—John Delafield Esqr. Revd. Dr Milnor and Mr Halsey— A Resolution was passed authorizing the Committee to call the first Meeting of the Society at such time and place as they may deem expedient—and that they take measures to obtain an act of incorporation— It was agreed that the Convention should adjourn to-morrow— I did not attend this afternoon’s Meeting.— In the decisive measures for constituting the Society the only difficulties were in the Committee— There were none in the Convention— Mr Gallatin and other members had a repugnance almost invincible to assume the attitude of constituting ourselves a National Society of Literature Science, and the Arts—and Mr. Gallatin proposed that we should elect 100 members to constitute the Society, excluding ourselves altogether— I said it seemed to me that under the appearance of a fastidious delicacy this would be assuming much more than it would be to invite associates to join us in the formation of a Society— For while disclaiming all pretensions of literature and science ourselves, we should select one hundred men without consulting them and without concert among them—and summon them to constitute a Literary and Scientific Society— We were placed in the dilemma of forming a self-constituted Society, or passing a Self-denying ordinance, and of the two I preferred the former— After the adjournment I called to visit Mr and Mrs C. A. Davis, and Mr W B. Lawrence, none of whom were at home— I had received an invitation to an Evening party at Mrs Davis’s, which I was obliged to decline— The Revd. Mr M’Ilvaine of Brookline attended the Convention this morning, and I requested him to inform Miss Roberdeau that I should not leave the City till Monday Morning, which he promised to do.— I dined at Mr Philip Hone’s with a large party of Gentlemen and several Ladies. I had much conversation with Ex-Chancellor Kent and urged him earnestly to give his aid to the establishment of this new Society which he said he would; but faintly— It is considered as an Institution hostile to the Columbia College— I told Mr Kent I would shew him some of my Poetry— We had at table much Conversation upon Shakespear Othello and Hamlet— And Mr Hone invited me to take at any time a seat in his box at the Park Theatre— Dr Matthews called for me in the Evening and took me to a Club party and supper at Mr. De Rham’s— Here I met Professor’s Renwick—M’Neven, Smith, and several other Gentlemen whose names I could not ascertain. Among these was an Englishman, who told me that he had been at Dr Nicholas’s School at Ealing with my two Sons. He said Dr. Nicholas was dead. I had this day a visit from Dr. J. W. Francis— Home to my lodgings at Midnight
5— VI. Saturday.

Mr Sullivan spent half an hour with me this Morning.— A person by the name of Davis Hunt came and introduced himself to me as an Anti-Mason— He gave me a Sermon, preached by Lebbeus Armstrong a seceding Mason late Pastor of the Presbyterian Church of Northampton and Edinburgh in the State of New-York. It was delivered in Edinburgh, Saratoga County on the 12th. of September last; and published by request— Mr Armstrong’s Sermon is upon the murder of Morgan, but Mr Hunt is a disappointed applicant for an Office in the Custom-house, and suggested to me that there was much mismanagement in that department since a newspaper libeller, a Jew by the name of Noah has been appointed Surveyor of the Port— He says he has filled the subordinate offices of the Customs with Jews, his relatives and that they are fattening like leaches upon public plunder— I attended the Literary Convention, which after some closing business, and a prayer from Dr. Yates, adjourned without day— A vote of thanks was passed to the City Corporation for the use of the Hall and to the President for the fair and impartial discharge of his duties— I returned my thanks as well as I was able, but with a mortified feeling of deficiency in words to express that which I would have said.— My remarks were well received, and perhaps not the worse for their unpretending simplicity— That this business has gone through without discreditable exposure of incompetency for so high and distinguished a position I give thanks to God— After the adjournment of the Convention, the Committee for electing members of the Literary Society remained in Session about an hour— Each member present gave a list of the persons in the United States whom he thought best qualified to be members of the Institution and they were classed, each in one of the four divisions of the Society. I gave a list chiefly of Citizens of Massachusetts.— The members of the Committee Residents in the City of New-York agreed to have a meeting next Thursday Evening to proceed further in making their Selections. I returned to my lodgings. General Swift and Mr. James Monroe called on me there— General Swift brought me a note from Miss Roberdeau mentioning her disappointment that I had not gone this Morning and saying that she must go on Monday— I desired General Swift to assure her that I would meet her at the boat Monday Morning— James Monroe appeared to be under great anxiety, from a fear of the publication of John Rhea’s Letter, stating as facts things which Mr Monroe denied in the Article of death to be true— He said Mr Gouverneur had called upon me several times, but I had been absent from my lodgings— I dined with the Revd. Dr. Matthews with only his family. His wife and two daughters— He is a presbyterian Clergyman of great respectability, and has taken the most active interest in these Literary Conventions, in the Establishment of the new University, and in the formation of the new Literary Society— He had early in the week invited me to dine with him this day; but I had then declined under the expectation of leaving the City this Morning. Afterwards I made a conditional engagement with Mr Pitcairn— But when I concluded to remain till Monday Dr Matthews immediately claimed his former invitation as an engagement, and I wrote a note of apology to Mr. Pitcairn, who had reminded me of my conditional promise to him—and I offered to dine with him to-morrow if it should suit his convenience, but he was engaged. Dr. Matthews conversed with me fully upon his anxiety for the Establishment of this new Literary and Scientific Institution; and seemed to expect much aid to it from my co-operation.
I assured him I should be happy to give it any assistance in my power, but expressed to him my full conviction that all the real usefulness of such an Institution must be accomplished by the zeal and energy of the members Resident in the City— Of this he appeared to be sensible, but he enquired, if upon the organization of the Society, I should be elected its President, I should be willing to deliver an Inaugural Discourse at its first Meeting— I told him I should be willing to do any thing within the compass of my power— From dinner I went and spent part of an Evening with Ex-Chancellor Kent—talking of his Commentaries—of Blackstone and Woodeson—Mansfield Pothier Emerigon and Valin—Common Law and Civil Law—Littletons Tenures and Justinian. I read to him my Stanza’s on the foot of Penn’s Hill—which he approved—but which reminded him too much both of Gray’s Elegy and of Goldsmith’s deserted Village— I also talked with him and his Son of Shakespear’s Othello and Desdemona, Juliet, Imogen and Miranda.— I observed to him how much of the charm and interest of the Tragedy of Romeo and Juliet, depended upon the age of Juliet—a child—in her fourteenth year. How emphatically the Poet had marked that age; and how stupidly the Stagemen had changed the age from fourteen to nineteen— I said I took little interest in the character of Desdemona; whose sensual passions I thought over ardent so as to reconcile her to a passion for a black man— And although faithful to him I thought the Poet had painted her as a Lady of rather easy virtue—very different from the innocence of Miranda, or the rosy prudency of Imogen— The Chancellor did not entirely agree with me in this estimate of Desdemona— His Son still less— They thought better of my view of the character of Hamlet.— I spent the close of the Evening with George Sullivan, and his family.— I have taken a very severe Cold and Cough— I received Notes from D. H. Burr with proposals for subscription to a Geographical work upon the State of New-York; and from Messrs. Harpers requesting me to view their printing Establishment for which I have not time.
6. V. Sunday.

I set out this morning with Mr George Sullivan, to go and hear Dr Hawkes preach; but on the way we met one of Mr Sullivan’s sons returning who told us that Mr Hawkes was confined at home, with a cold and hoarseness, and would not preach either morning or afternoon. We went therefore and heard Dr Matthews preacher at what is called the Dutch Church—but there is nothing of the dutch language left in the City— The only difference to be remarked in the forms of service in this Church from those of the Presbyterian and Congregational Churches is that here the people sit during the Pastor’s prayer as well as during the Sermon. They perform no part of the service either standing or kneeling—the Sermon of Dr Matthew’s was temperate and sensible—not brilliant— Its doctrine was not Calvinistic—for his doctrine was that the Salvation of men depended upon themselves— He gave notice that Dr Coxe would preach at that Church at seven this Evening, on revivals in Religion. After Church I called upon Mr. William L. Stone Editor of the Commercial Advertiser at his lodgings— He had sent me word by Mr Stansbury that he was confined to his chamber by a severe attack of the influenza. I found him still in his chamber though convalescent— I had a conversation of an hour with him upon the proposal which he had made to me, of publishing addressed to me a series of Letters upon Masonry and Anti-Masonry— I asked him, if I understood him well, that his object in that publication would be the abolition of the Institution of Free-Masonry in the United States— He said certainly—that was and had long been his most earnest desire. I then observed that I hoped he would then take no views of the subject; the tendency of which
would be favourable to the continuance of the order— I had reference chiefly to a passage of his letter to me in which he stated that one object of his publication, would be to give a view of the good which Masonry had done and was designed to produce heretofore. I told him that since my last Conversation with him, a Sermon by Lebbeus Armstrong had been put into my hands, in which it is charged not positively as a fact, but as a report— It is said, that the grand Generalissimo of the American Encampment, wrote to some of the Western Lodges directing that Morgan’s publication must be suppressed cost what it would, even to the shedding of blood— The Generalissimo of the American Encampment is not named, but it was De Witt Clinton— Mr. Stone said Mr. Clinton had been grossly slandered upon this subject— That when the manuscript was fraudulently obtained from him, a special Messenger had been employed to bring it to New-York— That the Grand Chapter were then in Session, and there were then delegations meeting with them from other grand lodges in various parts of the United States— That Samuel L. Knapp was then a delegate from the grand lodge at Boston— That the Messenger delivered the Manuscript, in great agitation— That it was referred to a Committee of which Knapp was Chairman—who reported that the manuscript was private property and should be returned to the person to whom it belonged— And Stone said he never heard a severer rebuke than was then given by Mr Clinton who presided in the Chapter to the Messenger who had brought the manuscript and who was very unwilling to take it back— This was on the 12th of September and the Messenger must have left Batavia, before Morgan’s arrest which was on the 10th.— This Story of Morgan in the hands of Scott or Cooper would make a novel or romance of irresistible pathos—and what a Drama would Shakespear have made of it?— Mr. H. W. Storrs heretofore a member of Congress from the western part of the State, but now a resident in the City, and a fellow lodger in the same house with Mr Stone came up to his chamber after dinner— And also Mrs Stone— I came away, and dined in family with Mr Sullivan— After dinner I visited Mr. Saml. L. Gouverneur—and saw there Mrs. Gouverneur, Mrs Hay—and Messrs. Price, Livingston, and De Peyster who had been dining there— In the Evening I went with Mr Sullivan, and heard Dr. Samuel H. Cox deliver a Sermon upon Revivals of Religion— He took three texts one from the Prophet Zachariah—one from Paul’s Epistle to the Galatians, and one from the Epistle to the Ephesians as illustrative of each other— Dr. Cox is eloquent— His mode of delivery is rather that of grace, and interesting conversation than of written composition.— His language is scriptural, not wholly void of elegance, but not remarkable for it— He made an observation upon Hume’s argument against the credibility of Miracles, which struck me as new and ingenious— He said the Evidence of the Miracles of Christ was so full, so strong and irresistible that Hume despaired of questioning the facts, and that his forlorn hope of argument was to maintain that no Evidence could prove Miracles— He knew that if the evidence could once be admitted, it was overwhelming it was vain to attempt with standing it— His only resource was to exclude it altogether— The house was very much crowded, and I understood there was now a Revival in full operation in the midst of this City— Dr Cox, with whom I some years since made a passage in a Steam-boat to Providence has been very kind, and civil to me here— He has constantly attended the Literary Convention; and has taken an active part in their proceedings.— He brought and introduced to me his two Sons; and sent me a Sermon recently preached and published by him—entitled Salvation achieved only in the present Life—which I am to read hereafter— I went home and supped with Mr Sullivan. Dr. John W. Francis came in and sat with me an hour— He took back the life of Sir Humphrey Davy in two Volumes— I regretted I could not even skim over it; but who is sufficient for these things? Every instant of my time here has been absorbed— Dr. Francis gave me his Address delivered on the 15th. of May last to the Philolexian Society in Columbia College, in which there is a very interesting biographical Memoir of the late Chancellor Livingston— I had written Letters this Morning to my Sons John at Washington and Charles at Boston— Packed up my Trunk and bag to be ready in the Morning— It was half past one A.M. when I went to bed.
7. V. Monday— From New-York to Philadelphia—

I rose at five, and before leaving the hotel, finished my version of the 35th. Psalm— I took a hack and Mr. Sullivan accompanied me to the boat. It was the Steam-boat Swan; and I found Mary Roberdeau at the wharf, ready to embark— The boat left the wharf precisely at seven— Of my fellow-passengers, were Coll. Thomas H. Perkins, Coll Loammi Baldwin, and his wife, with a young Lady of Norfolk, Virginia, who has been at the Convent in Charlestown at School, and is going home, and Mr. Hector Craig, heretofore a member of Congress from the State of New-York— We arrived at New Brunswick at eleven, and there took the Stages— Coll. Baldwin, and his Ladies, Coll. Perkins, with Miss Roberdeau and myself were in one Stage and reached the landing seven Miles South of Trenton at half-past two— There were two of the twelve Stages of our Company, which broke down but no person was hurt— At five O’Clock just before Sunset we landed at Philadelphia. I engaged a hack for Miss Roberdeau, and placed her in it; directing her Coachman to drive to her Mother’s at 80. Twelfth Street— I went first to Head’s Mansion house but there was no room there— I then came to Congress-Hall— Third and Chesnut Streets where they first gave me a single bedchamber, but afterwards changed it and gave me also a very good parlour.— I supped with Coll. Baldwin and his family, and then called upon Mr John Sergeant at his house, and spent a couple of hours there— Edward Ingersoll came in while I was there— I expected to have found a Letter here from Mrs. Adams but there was none—
8. VI. Tuesday.— Psalm 36.

Began the version of the 36th. Psalm— I called at Dr. Physick’s house for the purpose of consulting him upon the state of my health; but his Servant told me that he was ill, and could see no one— I then called at the house of Dr Mease, expecting to find Miss Mease there, but she was at his Son’s— I went to Mrs Roberdeau’s and saw her and Mary and Selina. Next I went to the house of Dr Mease’s Son, and there saw Miss Mease— Mrs Adams had written to me last Wednesday that she proposed to return and meet me at Philadelphia in a week, and that she would write to Miss Mease to engage lodgings for us— But Miss Mease had received no Letter from her— I called at judge Hopkinson’s but he was not at home— Then at Mr. Duponceau’s, and I had an hour of Conversation with him— I found him not pleased with the Literary Convention at New-York—nor with the Literary and Scientific Society instituted there— He thought it would injure the American Academy of Arts and Sciences at Boston, and the American Philosophical Society at Philadelphia— He also reproached me for having spoken of them as dead bodies—and observed to me that even now the Philosophical Society were publishing a Volume of Transactions— He spoke much to me also about his old-friend Court de Gebelin— He invited me to dine with him to-morrow, which I accepted— I met Josiah Randall in the Street— Judge Hopkinson and Mr Robert Walsh paid me visits,—and also Judge Baldwin of the U.S. Supreme Court. I dined at Mr John Sergeant’s— Edward Ingersoll and Joseph Reed junr were there— Three daughters of Mr. Sergeant were there, but their mother did not appear— He told me it was because last night she had lost her friend Mrs M’Pherson, the daughter of Bishop White— I came out with Edward Ingersoll, and went
home with him— He shewed me the second Edition of the Biography of the Signers of the Declaration of Independence, and told me that besides the life of my father in that work he had written the Lives of Samuel Chase, of William Paca, Thomas Stone, John Hart, and James Smith—and that young Gilpin wrote the Lives of Jefferson, Ross—Rodney, and Roger Sherman.— The second Edition is published by W. Brown and C. Peters, and has fac-similes of the autographs of the signers— Ingersoll spoke also upon the subject of Masonry and Anti-Masonry— I went with him to Mrs Swords’s and visited Mr and Mrs J. S. Johnston of Louisiana— Young Gilpin was there.
9. V: 30. Wednesday.

Calling at the Post Office to enquire for Letters, but of which there were none, I met Richard Peters with whom I went to Mrs Swords’s and visited Chief Justice Marshall— I found him sitting up in an easy Chair. He has recently gone through the terrible operation of cutting for the Stone—performed by Dr. Physick, from which he is now recovering— It was a case of extreme severity, and a moment of indiscretion in setting up and writing a Letter, too soon, brought on a haemorrhage and chills by which his life was greatly endangered, and for one day was despaired of— He is now almost recovered; and intends to leave this place in time to hold the U.S. Circuit Court at Richmond on the 22d.— I called again at Dr Physick’s house, and saw him at his Office.— I gave him an account of the state of my own health—of the thorn in the flesh which has pursued me little less than forty years—of my habits and courses of remedy, and of the cough which has harassed me almost constantly the last four years— He said he would call at my lodgings to-morrow Morning— I met Mr. H. Middleton, who came with me to my Lodgings— I thanked him for the Russian Platina Coins he had sent me, and asked him many questions concerning this operation of the Russian Government: all of which he was unable to answer—but he said he would make enquiries for me of Count Cancrin the Russian Minister of finance— Mr Middleton gave me also a copy of a printed Letter from him to his Constituents in South-Carolina, who had elected him a delegate to the Anti-Tariff Convention lately held in this City— I called upon Nicholas Biddle at the U.S. Bank; and received two dividends of my bank Stock, by an order upon the branch Bank at Washington. I left with Mr Biddle my Certificate of Stock to be sold, and the proceeds to be remitted according to such directions as I may give— I told him that as I might be called to take a part in public measures concerning the bank and was favourable to it— I wished to divest myself of all personal interest in— I indorsed my name in blank on the certificate. Dined with Mr. Duponceau.—W. Short—John Vaughan—Charles J. Ingersoll and Mr Garesche were there— Paid an Evening visit to Mr M’Kenney at his lodgings— Attended the theatre, and witnessed the performances of Master Burke an Irish boy, about twelve years old— He enacted the part of Doctor Pangloss in the Heir at Law, and of Looney M’Twolter in the Review or the Wags of Windsor, and between the two he played the overture of Don Giovanni upon the Violin, accompanied by the Orchestra— He is one of the twelve year old prodigies—of whom I have seen many who came to nothing in mature age— The part of Dr Pangloss was as ill-suited for him as possible and he performed it very indifferently— Nothing of the starch and precise pedantry which constitutes the essence of the character, and include all its humour.— His Looney was better, and his Irish song was encored— His performance on the Violin was excellent— His face and manner are entirely boyish— Home to my lodgings about Midnight.
10. VI. Thursday.

Finished the version of the 36th. Psalm. Dr Physick came this morning as he had promised, and after a full and severe examination had no other advice to give me than patience— He thought if he should take away the immediate cause of my complaint it would be thrown back upon my lungs—and that to remove the superfluous tumour on the head would require confinement for several days and might be followed by an attack of Erisypelas. I requested his bill, but he said he had none—for he had done nothing— I received this Morning a Letter from my wife; who speaks doubtfully of coming here, but thinks if she does of bringing John’s youngest child with her— She desired me to apply to Miss Mease, to ascertain if lodgings could be procured at Madame Coulon’s where some years since Mr Thomas B. Johnson lodged. Dr Mease called on me, and said that Miss Mease was confined to the house with a swollen face, but offered to go with me himself to Madame Coulon’s and went— The apartments are not so neat as when they were occupied by Mr Johnson, and the furniture is several years older After a short visit to the Athenaeum I went with Mr. M’Kenney to the Rooms of a young Artist by the name of Inman a very promising painter— He had there a very fine Portrait of Chief Justice Marshall—much superior as it appeared to me to that of Harding. There was also a Lithographic establishment engaged upon a work of Natural History by two young men of the name of Doughty—and for which work I subscribed— I wrote to Mr Middleton making the enquiries concerning the Russian Platina Coins and metal, and left my Letter at his lodgings not finding him at home— I made enquiries also upon the same subject of Platina, of Professor Keating, who promised to inform me where I could find the best account of that Metal.— Frederick Poger, was a trader who visited me from the western part of the State; merely for curiosity— I dined with Richard Peters and a company of ten or twelve gentlemen. Judge Baldwin. Mr Poindexter—C J. Ingersoll, R. Walsh, judge Hopkinson, and others— Mr W. Keating accompanied me home to my lodgings in the Evening.
11. V. Friday.

Began the version of the 37th. Psalm. Dr Physick called on me again this morning— I told him, I had concluded to do nothing further at present for myself, but should proceed to-morrow morning for Washington; and if Mrs Adams should return here might perhaps come with her.— Mr. Vaughan and Mr. Connell paid me visits. Mr Gorham of Boston and his Son were yesterday here and proceeded Southward— Mr Henderson Inches and his two Sisters with Miss Brimmer are at this house and have a parlour adjoining to mine— He called upon me yesterday, and I visited him and the Ladies this Morning. Mr M’Kenney was here again to day, and I paid several morning visits—to Chief Justice Marshall whom I found still recovering and in fine Spirits— He said he expected to leave this place next Thursday for Baltimore—to go thence by the Steam-boat to Norfolk and
to reach Richmond in time to open his Court on the 22d— He never had been absent at any one term since he had been in office, and he said he was very anxious not to be absent now— At Mr Middleton’s lodgings, but he was not at home— At Charles J. Ingersoll’s— He told me that his brother Edward was a Mason; though he himself was not—nor his brother Joseph— Edward whom I afterwards met in the Street, acknowledged that he had been admitted in a Lodge some years ago— I returned the visit of Mr James Brown, but he was not at home— Visited Mr Walsh with whom I sat and had a Conversation of perhaps an hour— He spoke with great admiration of the Diplomatic Correspondence of our Revolutionary War, recently published by order of Congress and edited by Jared Sparks. I called on N. Biddle, at the U.S. Bank— And examined Apartments for lodgings, in case Mrs Adams should return here— At the House where I am— At the United States Hotel; where Renshaw has abdicated but which is to open next week with a new Landlord— I went also to Mrs Purdon’s where Mrs. Adams had formerly lodged; but who has not now sufficient accommodations disengaged. I called at Weaver’s where Mrs Adams had left the Carriage, and at Schenk’s where she had left the horses— Weaver asked 200 dollars to repair the Carriage, and 475 dollars boot to exchange it for a new one. Schenk said he could have sold the horses a few days since, but the chance was now lost— I met J. Sergeant, and went with him to dine at Nicholas Biddle’s.— A large party— I met there Messrs. de Tocqueville and de Beaumont, the Commissioners of the French Government, with whom I had dined at Alexander H. Everett’s in Boston— Also Judges Baldwin and Hopkinson—Mr Poindexter—Warren S. Davis, Charles J. Ingersoll, R. Walsh and Mr Huntt a brother of Dr Huntt of Washington— In the Evening I attended a Meeting of the American Philosophical Society and met there Mr Vaughan, W. Short—Dr. Chapman—Professor Keating, Mr Richmond, Mr Harlan and some others— Audubon’s late Magnificent work upon American Birds was there— The Oriole of Baltimore is the fiery hang-bird. There were several new publications—among which Todd’s new Method of Induction. Home to my lodgings about eleven— Settled my bill to be ready for the morning.
12. V. Saturday.— From Philadelphia to Baltimore.

At seven this Morning I left Philadelphia in the Steam-boat William Penn, Captain Jeffries— Mr John Vaughan according to his frequent practice met me in the Street, and accompanied me to the boat, where he took leave, after introducing to me, Mr. Barclay a respectable citizen of Philadelphia, a fellow passenger to Baltimore on a visit to his two Sons, whom he had placed at the Jesuits College there. His reason for placing them there he said was that the discipline at that College was more severe than at any other in the United States— There were numerous other passengers, none of them however known to me, except Mr William B. Adams of Marblehead, who claimed acquaintance with me, from the time of my Residence at St. Petersburg in 1810. and whom I saw at Marblehead when I visited that place with the late Governor Eustis in 1824— He has been since, and may be now a member of the Massachusetts Legislature; and being a
man of pliable principles, is going to Washington I suppose in search of a place. There was a Mr Janvier of Philadelphia, who introduced himself to me, but who disembarked with his horse at Newcastle.— At Chester there came on board three new passengers concerning whom suspicions were circulated round the boat that they were of the order of Industry; but they exhibited no proofs of it this day— At half past ten we took the barge at the Delaware City— Passed the lock and a marble Tablet erected on the bank of the Canal to commemorate the accomplishment of the work— We reached the black River landing at one, and took the Steamboat Charles Carroll of Carrollton Captain Chaytor— The weather, chilling cold confined me almost the whole day to the Cabins of the boats— I had no book to read, no pleasant fellow traveller for conversation, but I composed four Stanza’s of the version of the 37th. Psalm, and they amused the day— At six in the Evening we reached Baltimore, and I took a bed-chamber at Barnum’s Hotel supped at the Ordinary. In the Evening I was visited by Mr Robert H. Goldsborough, Mr Jenifer a member elect of Congress from Maryland—and Mr Breck, recently from Kentucky, and a delegate to the National Convention to meet at Baltimore on the 12th of next Month to nominate a Candidate for the Presidency. Isaac Munro, the Editor of the Baltimore Patriot afterwards came in— He had been this day with the Directors of the Railroad, and a party of about 100 forty miles and returned— Left here at 8 this morning— Stayed two hours at the end of their ride and dined, and returned here by six this Evening— After Mr Munro left me I passed the remainder of the Evening, writing.
13. VI:30. Sunday— From Baltimore to Washington—

Took the Stage from Barnum’s at half past eight this Morning— In the Street at Baltimore we passed into a Rail-road Car in which with a single horse we rode eight miles in about three quarters of an hour— We then passed into the Stage again and came rapidly the remainder of the way. Mr R. H. Goldsborough was a passenger; and Mr. W. B. Adams, our Steamboat companion of yesterday— Mr Snowden was a way-passenger, and there was one other— The Stage stop’d at Gadsby’s, and in the Street before the house, was standing Edward Wyer in precisely the same spot where I had left him on the 21st. of April last— At half past two I alighted at my Son’s house, and met Mr Daniel Brent before the door— I have to thank almighty God, that my journey and that of my family is thus safely completed, and that we are all safely landed here— But both my son John’s children are unwell— Louisa with a severe cold, and the infant with an ulcerated mouth succeeding very dangerous Summer complaints— I had an Evening visit from General Macomb, and found here several Letters, some of which have been here several days.— I return to Washington with less tranquility of mind than at the last and the preceding Winter— That before me is of an aspect to which I look with an aching heart.— One experiment which I have made upon this Journey has been successful as far as it could succeed— I mean that of employing my time— I have lost none— Since I left Quincy I have composed 23 Stanzas of versions of the Psalms—all bad—but as good as I could make them.
14. V:30. Monday— Washington.

According to my practices heretofore I resumed the reading of three chapters in the bible every day, beginning at the tenth Chapter of Genesis— Walked round the Capitol Hill, and composed two Stanzas of the version of the 37th. Psalm— In my walk I met Jonathan Elliot, who told me that he had lost his wife and one of his Sons on one day. I met also Colonel Roger Jones, adjutant General of the Army and his three Sons— William Lee, lately arrived with his wife from Boston, and Peter Hagner.— William S. Smith called on me before dinner; and Joseph M. White the delegate from Florida— Just returned, from an excursion into Virginia, where he saw Mr Madison, Governor Floyd, and others of their politicians— Floyd he says, is violently opposed to the present Administration of the General Government, and so are Tazewell and Tyler, but know not upon whom to concentrate their votes in opposition.— The grounds of opposition in all of them are indeed selfish and puerile— I ought now to have taken up seriously the arrears of this diary, but wasted almost the whole day in reading Newspapers.— There are curious and somewhat whimsical correspondences in the State of Massachusetts, connected with their Elections for the several branches of the State Government which takes place this day— Specially of Mr Samuel Lathrop the Anti-Masonic Candidate for Governor, and Mr Leverett Saltonstall a candidate for election as a Senator in the County of Essex—one at Springfield and the other at Salem— Mr White advised me to go and secure a Seat in the Hall of the House of Representatives.
15. IV:15. Tuesday.

Began the attempt to redeem the arrears of this Diary, which now stands at the 19th. of September— The minutes upon my Sybilline leaves have however been kept up from day to day— My arrears commenced about the 4th. of July, and went on insensibly increasing till when I left Quincy they had run up to five weeks, and there are now three more.— To bring them up will be a tedious if not an impracticable task— I finished this morning the version of the 37th. Psalm; and began this Evening that of the 38th. I walked to the Capitol; went into the Hall of the House of Representatives and bespoke the Seat N. 203. the same occupied in the last Congress by Mr Gorham, then the Representative from Boston— I also went in to the Congress Library and there met Mr Matthew St Clair Clark the Clerk of the House of Representatives, and Mr Joseph Gales, of the National Intelligencer at whose Office I had left a packet for him entrusted to my charge by Edward Ingersoll at Philadelphia— I made some enquiries at the Library of Congress, particularly for Birch’s History of the Royal Society—but it is not there— Neither are the first forty-five Volumes of the Transactions of the Royal Society itself— But I found a Volume of the Transactions of the Literary and Philosophical Society of the existence of which I scarcely knew before.— Among the Letters which I received upon my arrival here, was one from Samuel Martin of Campbell’s Station Tennessee, enquiring upon what terms Eastburn would allow him to print an Edition of the Eulogy upon Mr Monroe, of 2000 copies— I enclosed the Letter itself to Eastburn requesting him to answer it, as he should think proper, and with reference to his own interest and without regard to mine— I met this morning Dr Kent in the City—on horseback returning home to Bladensburg—
16. IV:30. Wednesday.

Morning walk round the Capitol Hill— My Son John’s youngest child is very dangerously ill, and has been so for three or four Months—with alternate apparent convalescences— She has now an ulcerated mouth, tongue, and throat, exceedingly painful and which keep her constantly crying— Dr Huntt was here to visit her, and thinks the primary complaint is the breeding of teeth— Mr Louis M’Lane now the Secretary of the Treasury left visiting Cards at my house— I received an invitation from General Macomb to dine with him to-morrow— I received also a printed circular Letter from W. F. Otis Nathaniel Brown, and George W. Bryant, a Committee from a Meeting in Boston, got up to petition the Legislature to abolish imprisonment for debt. The circular is addressed chiefly to the Clergymen of Boston; but the Committee were authorised to send it to other individuals—whomsoever they thought fit—and they have sent one to me— I began writing an answer, but did not finish it— I began reading Bernard’s Light on Masonry; and read the forms of admission of the entered Apprentice and Fellow Craft— It is matter of curious speculation, how such degrading forms, such execrable Oaths and such cannibal penalties should have been submitted to by wise, spirited and virtuous men— It is humiliating to the human character— Is it interest?—fear? pride? the danger or the mortification of retreating? Or is there something in the wild, incoherent mixture of pure morals and high religious devotion with secret and mystical rites and atrocious cruelty that has an irresistible influence over human action— The Mahometan Religion is a memorable example of this— Some of the bloody sacrifices of antiquity are to be accounted for only thus— I cannot think of it but with melancholy feelings.
17. IV:30. Thursday.

Finished the version of the 38th. Psalm— Visits from Judge Cranch; from Mr Cass the Secretary of War, and from General Macomb— Since I last saw Cass he tells me he has lost sixty pounds weight of flesh. He is in appearance a totally different man— He was corpulent to unwieldiness— He is now thin and spare— His two aspects resemble the Mason of 1826 and the Mason of 1831 on the title page of Giddins’s Almanac— I received Letters from Joseph Anderson the first Comptroller, thanking me for the copy which I sent him of the Eulogy upon Mr Monroe—from my Son Charles, and from Joseph Blunt— Judge Cranch read me extracts of Letters from his Son Edward who went last June, as a lawyer at Cincinnati in the State of Ohio— He appears to be well pleased with his situation; and writes in fine spirits and with grateful sensibility— The judge has great hopes of him as a young man of promising parts— The judge spoke also of his son John, who is at Florence in Italy, pursuing his Studies as a Painter.— Mr Cranch’s Son in Law Rufus Dawes and his daughter Margaret have been very ill, with bilious nervous intermittent fevers but are recovering— I dined with General Macomb— Mrs Macomb was not present— But there was his first wifes mother, a visitor from Detroit in the Territory of Michigan— Three daughters, one of whom
told me that she had just recovered from a desperate bilious fever Mr Gouverneur Kemble, Coll. House, Captain Childs, Lieutt. Williams, and several others— Coll Thayer, the Superintendent of the Military Academy at West Point was to have been of the party but was confined at his lodgings by indisposition.— My Grandchild continues very ill.
18. V:45 Friday.

Began the version of the 34th. Psalm—one of those with which I have found the greatest difficulty and of which I have been obliged finally to put up with a complete failure— There are some of which the versification comes to me almost as easily as prose— Some which I labour painfully for hours, and give up in despair; substituting a mutilated fragment for the whole Psalm—and some, upon which after ranging through many varieties of expression altogether dissatisfactory, I finally alight upon a turn which pleases my fancy— There is an agitation of mind in this habit of composition resembling the intense interest of a gamester in the fluctuations of his fortune; and not unfrequently I am quite delighted with my success in producing a Stanza, which upon reperusal a week after sickens me as flat stale and unprofitable.— I walked round the Capitol this morning— There was a double attack upon me this morning in the National Journal, which I take for the Clay Declaration of War— It has been preceded by clandestine hostilities enough.— I am still engaged in answering the Circular from the Committee on the question of imprisonment for debt: my opinions are not all favourable to their views, and it might be more prudent for me to give a short and unmeaning answer to them; evading in substance their question—but it is not in my nature— My life has been spent in stemming currents of popular opinions and until lately, with occasional and great success— But the runs of luck in life, are as at whist— The tide in the Affairs of men when it has once begun to ebb, will go down— This free and bold expression of my opinion which I disdain to withhold will hasten my down-ward course, and noting can redeem it— Let me fulfil my destiny; and so far as may be possible sustain my character— I read a few pages in Barnard’s Light on Masonry— The Master Mason’s degree— It grows worse as it proceeds— General Jesup was here this Evening— His wife is in Kentucky and to spend the Winter there— Dr Huntt visited the child—which is very alarmingly ill— My wife watches with her this Night—
19. IV:30. Saturday.

The child is yet most distressingly and dangerously ill; and in such circumstances nature is querulous; every object assumes a shade of darkness—the soul is under a harrow; and it groans— Father, forgive, restore and cheer— I finished the version of the 39th. Psalm—very badly; but the two Stanza’s of this day were most bitterly adapted to my condition and feelings— Could I have produced them as original compositions they would have been but too accurately suited to my Circumstances— Could I have even executed the version well it would have afforded me consolation— Real comfort is denied me.— I walked round the Capitol Hill— Received a Card visit from Levi Woodbury now the Secretary of the Navy— Received also several pamphlets from Mr Thomas S. Grimke of Charleston South-Carolina—among which was the exposition and protest of the Legislature of
South-Carolina in December 1828. written as Mr Grimké affirms by John C Calhoun— The Telegraph was first brought to me yesterday—and it contains a defence, well written, against the attack of me in the National Journal.— Mr Frye was here part of this Evening— My Letter to the Boston Committee upon imprisonment for debt is not yet finished, and it delays my journalising— Read a few pages of Bernard’s Light on Masonry, which I find exceedingly tedious— Edward Everett’s recent address to the New-York Institute is more entertaining and instructive.
20. IV:30. Sunday.

Began the version of the 40th. Psalm— Walk round Capitol Hill— At the second Presbyterian Church I heard Mr Smith from Luke 19.41. “And when he was come near, he beheld the city, and wept over it. 42. Saying, if thou hadst known, even thou, at least in this thy day, the things which belong unto thy peace! but now they are hid from thine eyes.[”]— The Sermon was not written, and it seemed to me that the mind of the preacher was not so copiously stored, as it should be to discourse extemporaneously— There was an obvious labouring for ideas and those which came had not been duly digested. He fell short of the expectations I had formed of him at the time of his ordination last Winter; and at his subsequent performances soon after— I received visits from Mr Hassler, with a friend of his from Switzerland, who has a large Collection of antient Greek, and Roman Coins— From Benjamin Ogle Tayloe, who is barely convalescent from a bilious fever, which has greatly reduced him— From Tench Ringgold heretofore Marshal of the District, and his Son— From Edward Livingston, Secretary of State, and from Thomas Munro, heretofore Postmaster of the City— Mr Ringgold said something about the Letter from John Rhea to James Monroe, so strangely got up here last June, which he thinks owing to the rancorous hatred of Jackson against Monroe.— A flat and wilful lie, sustained by testimony worked out of a man in his dotage by means profligate beyond all belief— The publication of these papers is threatened and suspended; to keep S. L. Gouverneur under a perpetual terror of losing his place as Postmaster at New-York— Mr Livingston was a member of the Literary Convention at New-York last year— Chairman of the Committee which reported the Resolution for establishing a National Literary and Scientific Institution, and also of a Committee which was to present at the Meeting of the present year, upon the expediency of establishing in our Universities and Colleges Professorships on the Theory of Legislation— The Report was not made to the Convention; but he promised, and now says it shall be made to the Committee for electing members of the Literary Society— Mr Monroe told me that after the death of the Russian Grand Duke Constantine, his Son Thomas had been made an Aide de Camp to the Emperor Nicholas— That he was sent with the remains of the Grand Duke to St. Petersburg where they were to be entombed— He said further that his Son had the intention of returning to this Country; though he did not know what he could do here— But he had no inclination to remain there— He said John Randolph while there had done all that was in his power to injure him but without effect— Mr and Mrs Frye were here this Evening— The child is yet
exceedingly ill— I went at seven this Evening to the Presbyterian Church to attend public worship again—but there was no service at that Time— I read some pages of opinions upon Masonry, and also part of the Introduction to Noyes’s new Translation of the Psalms. My Letter to the Boston Committee still unfinished.
21. VI.45. Monday.

Mr Palfray, the Minister of the Unitarian Church paid me a morning visit.— I returned by cards left at their doors the visits of Edward Livingston, Louis M’lane, Louis Cass, and Levi Woodbury, the Secretaries of the State, Treasury, War and Navy Departments Visited also Mr and Mrs William Lee; They occasionally go to the second Presbyterian Church and I invited them to take seats in my pew— Mrs Lee is a Lady of very serious and devout turn of mind.— I called next to see Mrs William S. Smith who has been for several years confined to her chamber with the Erisypelas.— Received Cards from W. T. Barry, the Postmaster General, and from Mrs Barry— Finished my Letter on Imprisonment for debt—in which without opposing the project of them who are pressing for the total abolition of it, I have endeavoured to impress them with the necessity of providing some other substitute for the security which it gives to credit. In this light it has not been viewed by those gentlemen— They consider nothing but the popularity of relieving prisoners from jail— I shall surely get no thanks from any one, for pointing to the consequences of their innovations upon the security of property and upon fidelity to contracts, as well as upon Credit— There was a great change of weather this Evening from a month fair and mild, to a very heavy peal of Thunder, and Snow— The child is most distressingly ill—
22. IV:45. Tuesday.

Finished the version of the 40th. Psalm and began the 41st. The ground was this morning covered with Snow, and the gale through the Night was tempestuous— The union of heavy thunder and sharp lightening with Snow, was a coalition of Elements almost as strange as that which terrified Horace into devotion—namque Diespiter, Igni corusco nubila dividens Plerumque, per purum tonantes. Egit equos volucremque currum. Ode 1.34. I walked round the Capitol Hill before dinner— Wrote to my Son Charles and read the remainder of Edward Everett’s Address to the New York Institute, and some pages of Opinions upon Masonry— This Institution of Free-Masonry is one of the phenomena in the History of mankind— That it is a most pernicious institution I am profoundly convinced—and how it has arisen—and grown, and spread over the world, and drawn into its vortex so many wise and good and great men is scarcely credible— There is however a charm in secret, and in exclusive association— In principle it is unjust, but in power it is great— Here is Secresy—there is the enjoyment of exclusive privilege— Then come Mystery—terrifying Ceremonies: horrid oaths and penalties; sprung upon the initiated by surprise— All mingled up with benevolence and Charity—with pretensions to antiquity coeval with the Creation—continual prayers and lessons from the Bible, mingled up with impostures about Solomon, Hiram King of Tyre, Hiram Abiff—John the Baptist and John the Evangelist—as absurd and senseless as they are false—Religion—Charity—pure benevolence and morals, mingled up with superstitious
rites, and ferocious cruelty, form in their combination Institutions the most powerful and the most pernicious that have ever afflicted mankind— They account for the prevalence of the Mahometan Religion— They governed the crusading ages— They are in great part the foundation of the Monastic Institutions; and especially of the Jesuits— I believe Free-Masonry to be an Institution less than two Centuries of Age, but it has undoubtedly borrowed much from others of higher antiquity—and probably something from the Eleusinian Mysteries.
23. V. Wednesday.

My Son’s youngest child is yet dangerously sick, and keeps us all in great distress. The winter has come upon us prematurely; and the Snow has not yet disappeared— I began a Letter to R. Rush, who requested of me a copy of the brief address which I made to the Queen of Great Britain, on theof March 1816—in sending it to him, extracted from my Diary at the time, the reflection upon the vicissitudes of my own life from that time to this, and upon the ravages of time and death which have since happened among those who were then great and happy gave a tinge of melancholy to my feelings, which creeps into the Letter— I called at the house taken upon the Capitol Hill, for Mr. White of Florida; and for his father in Law, General John Adair who is coming as a member of the House of Representatives from Kentucky Mr White was gone to Philadelphia, and I called upon Judge Cranch, whom I found suffering severely and almost laid up with Lumbago—a common inheritance of him and me— Returning home I called at Thompson and Homans’s shop, where I took ten numbers of Doughty’s Natural History, the American Almanack for 1832 and the second Volume of Sir James Mackintosh’s History of England— I received also at home a pamphlet on the Presidency, and a Globe Newspaper containing Mr White of Florida’s Letter upon live Oak Plantations.
24. V:45. Thursday.

Finished the version of the 41st. and began that of the 43d. Psalm. Prout is a black man who came to ask me to endorse a note for him at one of the banks. He is a stranger to me; though I had some relation with him, as a respectable coloured person when I was President— I could not comply with his request— Commodore Rodgers appeared to be much gratified with the change of Secretary at the head of the Navy Department. He now speaks of the late Secretary John Branch without reserve, and scouts his Cotton Canvass, and his retrenchment of the Live Oak Plantations in no measured terms— Coll. Gadsden has taken the place in the Corps of Engineers lately occupied by General Bernard who has returned definitively to France— Gadsden will not supply his place— Mr and Mrs Hawley were friendly visitors— Received Cards from Mrs. Rodgers, and from Genl. and Mrs Mason— In my walk to the Capitol Hill I met Mr Charles F. Mercer, a member of the House of Representatives from Virginia; and was shocked to see him almost as much as Governor Cass. He told me he had suffered three relapses of a bilious fever, followed by a severe attack of rhumatism—from all which he is but just now convalescent— I finished my Letter to R. Rush; and received pamphlets from P. S. Duponceau and Henry Warren. The latter an Oration delivered the last 4th. of July at Saint Albans in Maine.
My mind is restless, and full of floating Meditations and wavering purposes. The illness of my son’s child, which continues unabated, keeps the soul upon the rack, and it wanders in search of something to occupy and engage its wounded sensibility strange—that it should subside only into ridiculous trifles, like the bearded boys—
25— IV:45. Friday.

Finished the version of the 43d. Psalm— I had made one, of the 42d. in 1822. and after keeping it nine years, found myself unable to improve it, though it reads exceedingly flat— The 42d. and 43d. Psalms, are said by some commentators to form only one, I have therefore now finished the latter in the same measure which I had used for the other—discontented with both— Walked this morning round the Capitol Hill— Had a visit from Edward Everett, who arrived last Evening with his wife and four children— Mrs. Everett is unwell with a severe cold— Mr Everett is much concerned about Mr Clay’s prospects for the Presidency, but much gratified at his election to the Senate of the U.S—by the Legislature of Kentucky— He spoke with much reserve upon the Masonic, and Anti-Masonic controversy; and more freely about the Election of a Speaker to the House of Representatives— He has an extreme aversion to Andrew Stevenson the Speaker of the two last Congresses; and inclines to vote for Joel B Sutherland, a man of Stevenson’s own party but exceedingly eager to supplant him— They belong to the two Classes of Men of whom Hamlet says there is not a man in all Denmark included in the one, but is entitled also to rank with the other— But they are primi interpares—worthy competitors to preside over the Representatives of the Nation— Mr. Frye has lent me Morgan’s Illustrations of Masonry— I gave loose again this Evening to my reflections, and now sit down seriously to the task of retrieving the arrears of this diary—little short of two Months.— I had also a visit from Nathaniel Sheafe Waldron of New Hampshire; a brother of the Major Waldron who was here some year’s since. This young man told me that he was employed at the Navy-Yard; but he did not say in what capacity.
26. VI. Saturday.

Began the version of the 44th Psalm— Morning visit from Dr Sewall— Had conversation with him upon the different modes of warming rooms— I told him I had a suspicion that the Anthracite Coal, emitted into the atmosphere a subtle and impalpable dust which settled upon the lungs, and occasioned inflammation, colds and coughs— And generalizing the remark I expressed that all the modes of warming the atmosphere in cold weather, had material influence upon the health, and especially upon all persons with weak lungs— I advised him to write a Dissertation or Lecture upon the subject, which he seemed much inclined to do; and I thought it would come within the scope of Count Rumford’s donation to the Academy of Arts and Sciences at Boston, for prize dissertations on heat— He enumerated the different modes of warming rooms—by Coal of various kinds—by wood of various kinds—by open chimneys, by grates—by heated Stoves of brick and of iron—by Charcoal and by heated air circulated through pipes and flues from fires below— Each of these processes for communicating artificial heat to the atmosphere must affect in different degrees the lungs by
which it is breathed, and to these sources I believe may be traced a large portion of the consumptions which terminate so many lives— I received this morning a printed invitation signed by several inhabitants of this place, to attend a Meeting at the City Hall at half past six this Evening to consider the expediency of establishing a Lyceum in this City— I went accordingly— There were thirty or forty persons present— I was chosen Chairman, a Committee of five were appointed to report a plan of Constitution for a Lyceum which they did, and it was adopted Article by Article— A Committee was appointed to nominate Officers— They nominated me for President and Dr Laurie for corresponding Secretary— I desired to be excused, not being a permanent resident here; and when here much occupied— I was excused and Samuel Harrison Smith chosen President. The Meeting passed a vote of thanks to me for presiding; and a member proposed that I should be elected an honorary member— I had entered my name as an ordinary member and requested the mover to withdraw his motion which he did. I came home between nine and ten— There is a Letter in the Newspapers from Mr Clay, in answer to an Anti masonic Committee in Indiana— He refuses to say what his Sentiments upon Masonry are—because there is nothing about it in the Constitution of the United States— I received a Letter from my Son Charles
27. V:30. Sunday.

Heard at the second Presbyterian Church a Stranger from Acts 24.25. [“]And as he reasoned of righteousness, temperance and judgment to come, Felix trembled, and answered, Go thy way for this time; when I have a convenient Season, I will call for thee.” This is a very remarkable text, and susceptible of great variety of Comment. Sterne’s Sermon upon it is not to be forgotten— I once heard Dr Osgood of Medford deliver a very good discourse in his way upon it—and I have heard others.— Mr and Mrs William Lee were in my pew—and a notice was given that the communion would be administered the next Sunday— After Church I paid a visit to Mr and Mrs Edward Everett at their lodgings at Barnard’s— Mr Livingston the Secretary of State came in while I was there— Mr Everett sent me a number of the New-York Albion Newspaper containing a part of the debate in the House of Lords in England, upon their rejection of the Bill for Parliamentary Reform which had passed the House of Commons— An Article upon the Prospects of Reform in Europe written by Edward Everett, and published in the North American Review last July has been republished in London, and was much quoted in that debate, chiefly by the Peers in opposition to the Bill— I had read in the New-York American, an extract from a Speech by Lord Falmouth in which this Article was noticed— Everett had not seen it, and I sent him the New-York American, containing the extract from the Speech— After dinner I heard Mr Smith from Matthew 7.7—[“]Ask, and it shall be given you: seek and ye shall find; knock, and it shall be opened unto you. 8. For every one that seeketh receiveth: and he that seeketh findeth: and to him that knocketh, it shall be opened.” Mr Smith seems to dwell too much upon the
sufficiency of human exertion to work out its own Salvation, for an orthodox Calvinist. I received a Letter from Miss Eliza S. Quincy in answer to the one which I wrote to her from New-York—promising to send me the drawings that I had requested— I received also a French pamphlet of F. A. de Syon, a young man who was here with General La Fayette—and a pamphlet from Baltimore upon the claims on France before 1800—
28. VI.15— Monday.

This Mr Dana has in the Intelligencer of this Morning an Advertisement of a full column announcing the publication by him of a great work upon the Geography of North and South America— He brought me this Morning a Petition to Congress, that they would order all the Surveyors, and Officers of the Land-Office to furnish him with materials for his book, and that they would grant him the privilege of franking Letters by the Post-Office— The man appeared to me to be so illiterate, that I should have doubted his power to spell his own name. I told him I thought there would be great difficulty to obtain from Congress the prayers of his petition, for they could not enjoin upon any of their officers to furnish him materials for his book without making them compensation for extra labour; which they could not do from the public funds—and they could not set the example of granting to one individual the privilege of franking Letters, without obliging them to grant the same right to many others— He said he believed then he would give it up; although the work had been his employment for many years, and had cost him many thousand dollars. He kept me I think upwards of an hour, talking to me what I thought nonsense. I walked before dinner and called to see Mr. and Mrs Frye— I attempted to take down the Towns in the County of Plymouth—with a view to furnish their members in the Legislature with the public documents at the Commencement of the Session of Congress.— There is in the Boston Press of 22. and 25. November, a very remarkable Letter from Judge William Strong of Vermont upon the subject of Masonry— John spent the Evening abroad— His youngest child is apparently better.
29. V:45. Tuesday.

Finished the version of the 44th. Psalm—and began that of the 45th.—an Epithalamium— Remarkably different from all the other Psalms—and especially noticeable, as quoted in the Epistle to the Hebrews. Chapter 1, v. 8, 9. and there directly applied to Christ the Son of God— I selected for this Psalm a different measure from that which I have generally used for the rest; a six line instead of an eight line Stanza— I expected to have more difficulty than with any of the rest, and approached it with terror— I found it the easiest of all, and am better satisfied with it than with that of any other than I have yet undertaken— John Coburn was here— He was several years the Steward of Mr Monroe when President of the United States, and has a certificate of recommendation from him— Since Mr. Monroe went out of office he has kept a grocer’s shop, and now wishes to obtain the appointment of door keeper to the Senate— He came to solicit my influence, but I told him that was nothing, and advised him to apply to the members. Walk to the Capitol before dinner— I went in to the Hall of the House of Representatives, and saw that my name was entered upon the table of Seat N. 203. which I had selected—
General Macomb sent me several English Newspapers; among which the Morning Herald of 7. and 8. October containing the debates of the 6th. and 7th. in the House of Lord’s upon the Reform Bill. It was debated five days, and finally rejected by a majority of 41 votes on the 8th. It had passed the House of Commons by a majority of 109 votes after a dissolution of Parliament for the failure of the Bill, at a former Session— The progress of this principle of Parliamentary Reform in England since the triumph of the European Alliance over Napoleon in 1815 seems to me the most remarkable political phenomenon of modern times.
30. IV:45. Wednesday— Fahrenheit 18.

The Winter is setting in prematurely— My Thermometer this Morning was at 18. About three in the morning I was awaked by the tolling of the Bell of St. John’s Church, upon our Square, which continued for about an hour— It was a fire at Georgetown, which consumed a block of five brick dwelling-houses— The pumps were frozen so that they could get no water— The Steam Boats between the City and Alexandria were stop’d by ice in the river— I walked before dinner and left Cards for General Jesup, who was gone for a month to Kentucky; for Baron Stackelberg and Doctor Lovell—and paid a visit to Mr P. R. Fendall— He says he hears that a Candidate from Tennessee is to be started against Matthew St. Clair Clarke, for Clerk of the House of Representatives— Mr Clarke’s offence was that he accompanied Samuel D. Ingham the late Secretary of the Treasury to Philadelphia, after his ridiculous quarrel with John H. Eaton, the late Secretary of War— There was Snow this Evening, and I consumed precious time in reading the debates in the House of Lords upon the Reform Bill—

Day— It has been various through the Month— The first week at New-York, much occupied and amused with the literary Convention— I greatly fear with more of Show than of real substance— The second week at Philadelphia, visiting and dining with my friends—very pleasant, but not very pleasant, but not very profitable—consulting Dr Physick, and ascertaining that I must bear those ills I have, and wait for the consummation which the disposer of Events is preparing for me. The last seventeen days of the month I have been here, and except the writing of a Letter in answer to the enquiries from the Boston Committee upon Imprisonment for debt, my time has been swallowed up in a partial redemption of the arrears of this diary, which had accumulated to 54 days— I despaired of retrieving them, but have brought up forty though by adding seventeen to them— It is what the Sailors call a stern chase, always a long one— In terms of extreme occupation my daily record has more than once fallen into irretrievable arrears; and thus blanks have been made precisely at the most important periods of my life— It ought not to be so now, and a hiatus in my Journal at this time would be a lasting reproach to my indolence— Busy moments are however coming again, when it will be difficult to keep along with the current—and I have even now this whole month to redeem—
